column2: magrah, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen, more commonly known as "Vicodin", was prescribed for my chronic back pain, and while it was effective for a short period of time, I quickly built up a tolerance to it and the quantity needed to effect my pain levels became far to high. It is for this reason I do not believe Vicodin should be prescribed for chronic pain, and I also feel that ultimately, prescribing Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen for long-term or chronic pain will do the sufferer more damage than good. Vicodin acts quickly, but the effects fade just as fast and then the pain is back again, if not worse. Because the user must increase the dosage to combat the pain, questions of addiction arise, particularly from doctors who do not specialize in pain management. Unfortunately, opiates are really the only drug commonly used for the treatment of pain, and the risk of addiction is always present. HOWEVER, with the use of a long acting time released opiate, the pain becomes more manageable because it not only controls the pain better, it also works for a longer period of time, and for someone like me, with chronic pain due to degenerative disc disease, the absence of pain allows the muscles to relax, allowing for a release from spasm, and subsequently, also working to reduce pain  levels. Vicodin is great for a pulled tooth or perhaps a sprain, in other words, something that will get better, but will hurt for a short while. Taking this med is a balancing act as you do build up a tolerance, but so long as you do not increase your dose over time, you should be fine in terms of addiction. So taking more for a momentary increase of pain is OK, just so long as the increase is not sustained. Sometimes it's necessary to get ahead of the pain. When you return to the original dossaging be prepared for a lessened effect. This is the trade-off for taking an opiod based med. For me this is a miracle drug as it allows me to function. It has given me back my life. It doesn't have the totally euphoric effect of say codeine or fentinyl, but it doesn't have the disorienting sleepy effect either.
